Back during the pandemic, I was lonely so I used to share some of my life experiences on YouTube comment sections of videos I found wholesome.
I got attacked by trolls who twisted the stuff in my comments to call me a simp etc. I was not used to dealing with such people so I needlessly tried to engage with them, having my own insecurities at that time.

And then it struck my slow mind one fine day: “some men just want to watch the world burn”
I deleted the original comment thereafter, eliminating the substrate on which these potential fungi might grow.

I rarely comment on others’ videos now. But the suggestions given here made me remember my observations.

Connection terminated. I'm sorry to interrupt you, Elizabeth, if you still even remember that name, But I'm afraid you've been misinformed. You are not here to receive a gift, nor have you been called here by the individual you assume, although, you have indeed been called. You have all been called here, into a labyrinth of sounds and smells, misdirection and misfortune. A labyrinth with no exit, a maze with no prize. You don't even realize that you are trapped. Your lust for blood has driven you in endless circles, chasing the cries of children in some unseen chamber, always seeming so near, yet somehow out of reach, but you will never find them. None of you will. This is where your story ends. And to you, my brave volunteer, who somehow found this job listing not intended for you, although there was a way out planned for you, I have a feeling that's not what you want. I have a feeling that you are right where you want to be. I am remaining as well. I am nearby. This place will not be remembered, and the memory of everything that started this can finally begin to fade away. As the agony of every tragedy should. And to you monsters trapped in the corridors, be still and give up your spirits. They don't belong to you. For most of you, I believe there is peace and perhaps more waiting for you after the smoke clears. Although, for one of you, the darkest pit of Hell has opened to swallow you whole, so don't keep the devil waiting, old friend. My daughter, if you can hear me, I knew you would return as well. It's in your nature to protect the innocent. I'm sorry that on that day, the day you were shut out and left to die, no one was there to lift you up into their arms the way you lifted others into yours, and then, what became of you. I should have known you wouldn't be content to disappear, not my daughter. I couldn't save you then, so let me save you now. It's time to rest - for you, and for those you have carried in your arms. This ends for all of us. End communication.

I would just email or message companies directly with my ideas but most companies aren't actually that accessable and I wouldn't care if the message went straight In the bin I just don't want to be bothered by the idea myself and sending the idea off helps me with that.
The other issue that makes me a troll is my scientific view of the world. Whenever I mention any of my theories I get call a troll and that's just because my view doesn't match the consensus even when I am commenting on topic it seems that scientists don't want to hear what I have to say even though some of my main theory makes predictions about reality that can and will be tested inadvertantly. I don't seek or get too many responses I just have to much to bottle that's all.

2001 youview a site where everyone can upload and share videos.

2007 I told IBM they need to move from chess to natural language that the next challenge should be a quiz.
2001 I wrote a letter to Microsoft about my ideal os in it stating the need for a data interchange, that security should come with the os and how it would be more efficient to emulate 32bit on a 64bit os rather than embedding backwards compatibility in with the 64bir system.
2007 I sent Google an email stating how they would do well to integrate custom AI chips into their infrastructure.
I have many more examples to go beyond retrospect let's look at ideas I've had that's have yet to come out.
The Thermo optic pin for high GHz nanotech on an optical grid.
Try virtually before you buy advertising.

While that explains a PROBABILITY of a trolling, the finding is just as invalid as finding a religious psychopath. Going to church doesn't exempt their evilness out of church. It is also not a definite measure to define a troller as some people actually believe what they are saying as crazy as it may sound. In that case they are not "trolling" but rather have a extreme viewpoint. Example: If a democrat said "Trump sucked" on a republican platform you could not say he was trolling because he may actually feel that way. Some "trolls" are actually just a taking break from the norm and are well informed people that want to create public discourse. It's like a professor making a silly/naïve comment in college to engage the students. Yes, their are some sadistic intentions by some but some actually aim to create discourse from a little comment chaos. It being right or wrong is another debate in itself. What they really seek is validation from the responder that someone cares about the subject just as much as they do.

People can have different motivations for trolling. Some are stupid and some are cool. Trolling can be a way to vent or a coping mechanism for insecurities, but trolling is also often used politically or strategically to disorient your opponents. Online it can be used as a game to determine the strong and self-assured from the weak and stupid (the easily offended). Or it can just be a sort of joke you play on society as a whole, in an attempt to make people question social their socially normative beliefs.

Here's an anecdote.
Once I saw a girl from my town being trolled for being vegan on her Facebook, I didn't know her but I sent her a message saying I love that there are vegans near me and that I'm sorry that she was being trolled.
She never replied.
Some time later I saw a really pretentious picture on her insta and posted a troll comment. She went as far as asking people for my number to give me a monumental lecture that only showed she misunderstood what I was saying.
The thing that annoys me the most is that I when you are nice people tend to ignore it but when you are even remotely sarcastic you are likely to get a lot of negative feedback.
This isn't by all means an excuse to troll, I think outside of light, humorous trolling, no one should express hate because it's toxic for both ends. Anger is not hate.

I was left with options one and three. Here I debated but ultimately decided on the first option ruling that because I dislike bugs and I know others dislike bugs quite a lot, I would helping more by killing bugs than by cleaning toilets (plus, let's be real, no one wants to clean toilets). It's kinda sad when you're in an actuall discussion, trying to implement all your arguments and someone calls you a troll, just because you wont stop using your arguments.
Sure, as someone who tends to troll sometimes I know, that a troll would do the same, but people have to learn the diffrence. If there is defently no point in what the "opponent" is saying and you can't convince him about anything, no matter how good your arguments are and how bad his arguments are, you can be sure he's just having fun with you. If he really brings up new and good arguments and awnsers to your arguments, you can be sure that he's serious about it.
Well, most of the time.

So: Don't call everyone with a diffrent oppinion a troll, but don't feed OBVIOUS trolls. That's all you need to know.

If this video was made with malicious intent, it would qualify as trolling.
Trolling, is a practice that is misleading or fooling others in specific ways to either argue a point, to prove something, or to pull out a specific reaction. It is not pretending to be dumb, flamebaiting, or being an asshole.
The original definition of trolling, which since then has been skewed by brainless memers and other idiots, was to partake in an argument upon the side you're against and arguing as poorly as possible.

i.e. in a creationism v. science debate, a troll would partake the creationism side as a firebrand young-earth creationist and quote the bible as often as possible to expose the creationist side as religious fools trying to shove their worldview onto others.

Oh, and it sure is nice for someone claiming to be scientific to simply go "Oh, ignore someone you perceive to be a troll, because someone who disagrees your nonsense surely must be wrong". That'll surely work well.

Since I have been doing it since 1996 before there was a name for it. Some times though it's from people posting things that takes me all of five seconds to open another tab and prove them wrong with little to no effort. The rest of the time it's a investment on luring them in. Unlike the youngsters of today who just jump in, I find it more enjoyable giving them facts before warping it into a subtle mind screw. It gets a better response. As people for the most part become more worked up when they have put a emotional commitment to the debate.

The statistical "conclusions" present in this video are flawed at best. Using surveys given to self described "trolls" and then trying to glean useful information from them is ridiculous. The "trolls" would likely answer the survey questions with the most extreme and absurd answers possible just to "troll" the system. If trolls are sadists, then those that engage them and allow their feelings to be hurt by absurd speech are masochists. In my opinion, it is a sign that we live in the cushy first world when engaging in absurd, occasionally insulting, speech is considered sadism. Sticks and stones people.

Every time I'd say something, they'd say something back. I say something, so they say something, so I say something, so they say something.  But If I just rolled my eyes and stopped responding, they'd shut up, which is what I wanted in the first place.  They might think they'd "won" by getting the last word in, but I'll just let them think that. It turns out the only way to win is to not play.

This video doesn't seem to differentiate between people who are being mean on the internet, and people who are using heavy sarcasm to make a joke or to point out a different way of thinking.

The original meaning of troll in internet terms isn't "someone who is mean or abusive online" - it is someone who baits out arguments from others by making controversial statements. Good trolls don't say mean things at all (that is way too obvious and it defeats the purpose if your victims know what you are doing). They instead say things that sounds very reasonable and get others to think they are being serious which sparks a "debate" and hopefully conflict among the people who respond to your post. The best troll makes a single innocuous comment and then just watches other people fight among themselves over it.

This video is gobbledygook with a speck of barely in-context science in it. It's not about "trolls", it's simply about verbally abusive people online.

A Troll is a person who lures others into a heated discussion but is being ingenuine about it. The trolls goal is to goad the other person into a fury, by relying on that persons inflexibile attachment to their own opinion, typically.

This specific kind of prank is native to the internet, the way that telephone pranks, like "the jerky boys", are native to telephone tecnology.

What you are providing examples of aren't "trolling". your examples are only antagonistic behavior, which isn't special on or off the internet.

Furthermore, theres plenty of junk science out there. If the study you're citing started from the same insubstantial premises that you have in this video, than what they have uncovered may be useful or interesting knowledge about human behavior, but it doesn't build a case for what you are calling a "Troll". You are still engaging in a poor de-engineering of a formerly discrete and usefully descriptive word.

I think there is a degree of misunderstanding regarding trolling. The 'art of trolling' is to cause a maximum response with minimum provocation; the perfect troll is not actually abusive or insulting because that is of itself a reactionary type response. The motivation of a good troll is to cause provocation, not to be the reaction. So really good trolling is categorized by often rather subtle satire that results in a disproportionate response from those who read it. The whole "Vaccines don't save lives" thing isn't necessarily a trollish comment if you don't take the comment literally.

For many of the most destructive diseases, mortality rate was already severely on the decline. By the time the Measles vaccine, for example, was introduced nearly nobody died from Measles in previous years. This is true with many other diseases and illnesses, especially ones that thrive in unsanitary conditions. This would highly suggest that rather than focusing on vaccines, we should focus in improving the lives of people through investing in technologies and infrastructures that promote safe and sanitary living conditions. Improved sanitary conditions has had a far greater impact on mortality rate of almost any specific disease than their respective vaccine has, and it works across the board in preventing practically every infectious illness.

Had vaccines been prevalent in a setting such as Victorian Era England, they would've had a massive impact on lives. To say they save lives nowadays, though, is frankly being overly generous. No doubt you can find specific examples or situations where they'll have an impact on a micro level, but on the macro level they don't really save lives; at least not in the same way that other practices would.

That being said, getting a vaccine couldn't hurt.

Trolls aren't psychopaths, trolls are just bored people that need something interesting to do, like watch people get up in arms over irrelevant nothings and a few well placed words. Trolls' pleasure comes not from inflicting pain, but by getting people to react in extreme ways (I.e. lose their shit) over something inconsequential. It is funny when people do that because it breaks the illusion that humans are somehow more rational than animals. Trolls are really a symptom of a society that pretends to be 'civilized,' which, at a closer look is merely an insane and irrational competition in a chaotic sea of conflicting self-interests. Trolls are enlightened enough to see this while the rest of society pretends their choices are rational. The reality is humans live like a bunch of pigs chasing their desires from moment to moment, rationalizing decisions after the fact rather than truly choosing the moral, logical or rational path. So when someone points this fact out some people find it offensive but the display of cognitive dissonance by these people is very entertaining to watch, like a parent watching a child making cute assertions about something,, which they lack a understanding over.

TLDR: Trolls are smarter and morally superior to you. From their perspective you look like a fool and are thus easy to make fun of.

I believe the connotations of calling something sadistic is misrepresentative of what behavior is actually being observed.  same thing with the term psycopathy.  while these may be accurate and clinically correct terms their popular misusage makes their correct usage in this video appear harsher and obscure the message and the point.  you see trollism, for lack of a better term, or the act of trolling, is not fundamentally harmful to society and may be just the opposite.  the ability for someone to evoke a reaction, and therefore engagement, is useful and helpful in a variety of situations.  someone who is able to hit on someone's negative emotions and make them feel angry or defensive is similar to making someone feel calm and agreeable.  the troll highlights the edge cases, gives definition and reinforcement to our closely held beliefs.  the wit and bile of satre and Voltaire resonates through the ages as shining examples of the uses of trollism.  for you see, when you agree with the troll, you stop using negative words like sadism and psycopathy and instead use positive words like parody and criticism, maybe even social justice.  there are two sides to every coin and our society has weighted the coin to play against those that would speak against consensus.  those that would expose the beliefs of others and hold them up for examination and dissection.  democracy is not about unanimous agreement, but about dissent!  trolls protect america, and make it great....again! Any research on successful trolling strategies? For instance, what to do when being ignored by one's targets.

Agree, but I don't think it's the only issue. There's an effect called the 'online disinhibition effect', which seems to be associated with more confrontational and emotional behaviour. The presence of anonymity and reduction of social cues can lead to behaviours that are not common in real life, and people adopt internet-specific behaviours and norms. These factors combined generally force the general population to act differently online, be more abrupt and not consider other's emotions or perspectives as much.

I did a psychology study on this as my third year undergraduate dissertation (unfortunately it didn't get published). I used linguistic analysis software to find that discussions that occurred online vs face to face were more emotionally charged, both positively and negatively.
